concepts.concept_name: Counting forward and backward from 1 to 100
Reading and writing numerals from 1 to 100
Number names from 1 to 100 (one to one hundred)
Place value: tens and ones in two-digit numbers
Number before, after, and between for numbers up to 100

in_scope: Counting forward and backward from any number up to 100
Reading and writing numerals 1 to 100
Writing number names (one to one hundred)
Understanding tens and ones place in two-digit numbers
Finding the number before, after, and between given numbers up to 100
Forming two-digit numbers using tens and ones
out_of_scope: Numbers beyond 100 — covered in ICSE Class 2
Three-digit numbers and hundreds place — not in CBSE Class 2 scope
Expanded form of three-digit numbers
Indian and international place value systems

concepts.concept_name: Comparing two numbers using greater than and smaller than
Ordering numbers in ascending order (smallest to largest)
Ordering numbers in descending order (largest to smallest)
Finding number before, after, and between two numbers

in_scope: Comparing two numbers up to 100 using >, <, =
Arranging numbers in ascending order up to 100
Arranging numbers in descending order up to 100
Finding the number just before and just after a given number
Finding the number between two consecutive numbers
Finding greatest and smallest from a group of numbers
out_of_scope: Comparing three-digit numbers — not in Class 2 CBSE scope
Number line representation — simplified at this level
Comparison involving negative numbers

concepts.concept_name: Identifying even numbers up to 100
Identifying odd numbers up to 100
Rules for even and odd numbers (ones digit check)

in_scope: Identifying even numbers from 1 to 100
Identifying odd numbers from 1 to 100
Understanding that even numbers end in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8
Understanding that odd numbers end in 1, 3, 5, 7, or 9
Sorting a group of numbers into even and odd
Pairing objects to check even or odd
out_of_scope: Even and odd properties in addition or multiplication
Numbers beyond 100
Formal divisibility rules

concepts.concept_name: Addition of two single-digit numbers (addition facts)
Addition of two-digit numbers without carrying (regrouping)
Addition of two-digit numbers with carrying (regrouping)
Properties of addition: order does not matter (commutative)
Adding zero to a number

in_scope: Adding two single-digit numbers
Adding a single-digit number to a two-digit number
Adding two two-digit numbers without regrouping
Adding two two-digit numbers with regrouping (carrying)
Column addition (vertical format)
Understanding that changing the order of addends gives the same sum
Adding zero to any number gives the same number
out_of_scope: Addition of three-digit numbers — beyond Class 2 CBSE
Addition of more than two numbers at once
Mental math strategies beyond basic facts

concepts.concept_name: Identifying addition in word problems (keywords: total, altogether, in all, sum)
Solving one-step addition word problems with two-digit numbers
Addition word problems involving everyday objects and Indian context

in_scope: One-step word problems requiring addition
Problems using keywords like total, altogether, in all, how many more when combined
Problems set in Indian context (Indian names, rupees, Indian settings)
Problems involving objects children encounter daily (fruits, toys, books, pencils)
out_of_scope: Two-step or multi-step word problems
Word problems requiring both addition and subtraction
Problems with numbers beyond 99

concepts.concept_name: Subtraction of single-digit numbers (subtraction facts)
Subtraction of two-digit numbers without borrowing (regrouping)
Subtraction of two-digit numbers with borrowing (regrouping)
Subtracting zero from a number and subtracting a number from itself

in_scope: Subtracting single-digit numbers from single or two-digit numbers
Subtracting two-digit numbers without regrouping
Subtracting two-digit numbers with regrouping (borrowing)
Column subtraction (vertical format)
Subtracting zero from a number gives the same number
Subtracting a number from itself gives zero
out_of_scope: Subtraction of three-digit numbers — beyond Class 2 CBSE
Negative results (minuend is always >= subtrahend at this level)
Checking subtraction using addition

concepts.concept_name: Identifying subtraction in word problems (keywords: left, remaining, difference, less)
Solving one-step subtraction word problems with two-digit numbers
Subtraction word problems involving everyday objects and Indian context

in_scope: One-step word problems requiring subtraction
Problems using keywords like left, remaining, how many less, difference, gave away
Problems set in Indian context (Indian names, rupees, Indian settings)
Comparing two quantities to find how many more or fewer
out_of_scope: Two-step or multi-step word problems
Word problems requiring both addition and subtraction
Problems with numbers beyond 99

concepts.concept_name: Skip counting by 2s up to 100
Skip counting by 3s up to 30
Skip counting by 5s up to 100
Skip counting by 10s up to 100

in_scope: Counting by 2s starting from 2 up to 100
Counting by 3s starting from 3 up to 30
Counting by 5s starting from 5 up to 100
Counting by 10s starting from 10 up to 100
Finding the missing number in a skip counting pattern
Connecting skip counting to grouping objects
out_of_scope: Skip counting by numbers other than 2, 3, 5, and 10
Skip counting beyond 100
Formal multiplication notation at this stage

concepts.concept_name: Understanding multiplication as repeated addition (groups of)
Multiplication table of 2 (2 x 1 to 2 x 10)
Multiplication table of 3 (3 x 1 to 3 x 10)
Using the multiplication symbol (x) and reading multiplication sentences

in_scope: Understanding that 3 groups of 4 means 4 + 4 + 4 = 12
Writing multiplication as repeated addition
Times tables of 2 (from 2 x 1 to 2 x 10)
Times tables of 3 (from 3 x 1 to 3 x 10)
Reading and writing multiplication sentences using x
Using pictures or objects to show groups
out_of_scope: Times tables beyond 2 and 3 — covered in higher classes
Multiplication of two-digit numbers
Division as the inverse of multiplication — not yet introduced
Multiplication properties (commutative, associative) formally

concepts.concept_name: Comparing lengths: longer, shorter, taller, same length
Measuring length using non-standard units (hand spans, footsteps, pencils)
Introduction to centimetre (cm) as a standard unit of length

in_scope: Comparing two objects by their length or height
Using terms: long, short, tall, longer, shorter, taller, same length
Measuring with non-standard units like hand spans, footsteps, pencil lengths
Understanding why standard units are needed
Introduction to centimetre (cm) using a ruler
out_of_scope: Metre and kilometre — introduced in later classes
Converting between units of length
Measuring with a ruler precisely to millimetres

concepts.concept_name: Comparing weights: heavier, lighter, same weight
Ordering objects by weight (lightest to heaviest)
Simple weighing using a balance and non-standard units

in_scope: Comparing two objects as heavier or lighter by holding or using a balance
Ordering three or more objects from lightest to heaviest or heaviest to lightest
Using non-standard units (blocks, stones) to weigh objects
Understanding the concept of balance (equal weight)
out_of_scope: Standard units of weight (kilogram, gram) in detail
Weighing with a digital or spring scale
Converting between units of weight

concepts.concept_name: Comparing capacity: holds more, holds less, holds the same
Understanding full, half-full, and empty
Measuring capacity using non-standard units (cups, glasses, mugs)

in_scope: Comparing the capacity of two containers
Using terms: holds more, holds less, holds the same, full, half-full, empty
Measuring capacity using cups, glasses, or other non-standard units
Ordering containers by capacity
out_of_scope: Standard units of capacity (litre, millilitre) in detail
Converting between units of capacity
Volume of solids

concepts.concept_name: Reading time to the hour on a clock (o'clock)
Reading time to the half hour on a clock (half past)
Days of the week in order
Months of the year in order
Relating daily activities to time (morning, afternoon, evening, night)

in_scope: Reading time shown on a clock to the nearest hour (o'clock)
Reading time shown on a clock to the half hour (half past)
Identifying the hour hand and minute hand on a clock
Naming the 7 days of the week in order
Naming the 12 months of the year in order
Associating daily routine activities with parts of the day
out_of_scope: Reading time to the quarter hour or to 5-minute intervals
24-hour clock or digital time in detail
Calculating elapsed time or duration
Reading a calendar to find dates

concepts.concept_name: Recognizing Indian coins (1 rupee, 2 rupees, 5 rupees, 10 rupees)
Recognizing Indian notes (10 rupees, 20 rupees, 50 rupees, 100 rupees)
Simple addition of money (coins and notes) within 100 rupees
Making amounts using different combinations of coins and notes

in_scope: Identifying all Indian coins in circulation (Re 1, Rs 2, Rs 5, Rs 10)
Identifying common Indian notes (Rs 10, Rs 20, Rs 50, Rs 100)
Adding coins to find total value
Adding notes to find total value
Making a given amount using different combinations of coins and notes
Simple buying and selling scenarios within Rs 100
out_of_scope: Notes of Rs 200, Rs 500, Rs 2000 — beyond Class 2 scope
Subtraction with money (giving change) in detail
Decimal notation for money (rupees and paise)
Paise as a unit

concepts.concept_name: Identifying basic 2D shapes: circle, square, triangle, rectangle, oval
Properties of 2D shapes: number of sides and corners
Identifying shapes in everyday objects around us

in_scope: Identifying circle, square, triangle, rectangle, and oval
Counting sides and corners of each shape
Recognizing shapes in real-life objects (clock face is a circle, book cover is a rectangle)
Differentiating between a square and a rectangle
Understanding that a circle has no sides and no corners
out_of_scope: Pentagon, hexagon, and other polygons — introduced later
Area and perimeter of shapes
Drawing shapes with precise measurements
Angles of shapes

concepts.concept_name: Identifying 3D shapes: cube, cuboid, cylinder, sphere, cone
Faces, edges, and vertices of 3D shapes
Relating 3D shapes to real-life objects

in_scope: Identifying cube, cuboid, cylinder, sphere, and cone
Counting faces, edges, and vertices of a cube and cuboid
Recognizing 3D shapes in real-life (dice is a cube, ball is a sphere, ice-cream cone is a cone)
Understanding that 3D shapes can roll or slide
Differentiating between 2D and 3D shapes
out_of_scope: Prisms and pyramids beyond cube and cuboid
Nets of 3D shapes
Surface area and volume
Formal counting of edges and vertices for cylinder, cone, sphere

concepts.concept_name: Line of symmetry: folding a shape into two matching halves
Identifying symmetrical shapes and objects
Repeating patterns with shapes, colours, and numbers
Growing patterns (increasing or decreasing sequences)

in_scope: Folding a shape to check if two halves match (line of symmetry)
Identifying shapes that are symmetrical (circle, square, rectangle)
Identifying objects with a line of symmetry (butterfly, leaf)
Recognizing and extending repeating patterns (AB, ABC, ABB type)
Recognizing and extending growing patterns (1, 2, 3, ... or 2, 4, 6, ...)
Creating simple patterns with shapes or colours
out_of_scope: Multiple lines of symmetry — introduced in higher classes
Rotational symmetry
Tessellations
Complex number patterns involving multiplication

concepts.concept_name: Collecting data by counting objects or events
Recording data using tally marks
Reading and interpreting simple pictographs
Answering questions based on data (most, least, total, how many more)

in_scope: Counting and recording how many of each type (e.g., fruits, animals, colours)
Using tally marks to record counts (groups of 5)
Reading a simple pictograph where each picture represents 1 item
Answering questions like: Which has the most? Which has the least? How many in total?
Comparing two categories in a pictograph
out_of_scope: Bar graphs — introduced in higher classes
Pictographs where each picture represents more than 1 item
Mean, median, mode — not at this level
Creating pictographs from scratch (focus is on reading)
